Description: Iron key finger ring with three teeth. For a casket or box.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Town (Naukratis), 'south-west of the town at a high part' also 'near the bronze house' (cache of bronzes)
Curator's comments: A number of similar keys were found at Naukratis (Ashmolean Museum AN1888.189; Boston 86.355, 86.354, 86.353; British Museum EA 1885, 1101.82; Fitzwilliam Museum GR.72.1887; Montreal 2522a-c; Petrie Museum UC59869d). Roman parallels from the Fayum and Egypt in the Petrie Museum (UC71705, UC63742, UC63769-77, 83-5, 90; Petrie 1917, 60, pl.76, W200). The context is discussed by Petrie in his journal: 'An excellent key ring in iron was found near the site of the silver objects (south west town); it was apparently to be worn, having a raised bezil on it, I do not remember seeing such before. By pottery [sketch of the key] also found there I see the lot is all about the 1st or 2nd century AD (Petrie Journal 1884-5, 165-6). Roman parallels from Egypt in the Petrie Museum (Petrie 1917, 59-60, W. 168). Such key finger rings are associated with small jewel caskets and boxes from the 1st century AD to the 4th century AD, with parallels from Pompeii and Roman Britain (Cool 2016, 48). Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1917. Tools and weapons illustrated by the Egyptian collection in University college, London, and 2,000 outlines from other sources. London. on.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (p. 39, Pl. XX)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TD.02) (Phase 3)
